title: Can the bank reinstate a mortgage loan after we received a discharge from Chapter 7? Collectors wont stop calling please HELP
question: We filled and received a discharge chapter 7 on 12/12/2009, Mortgage Bank received a relief from the automatic stay, We did not do a reaffirmation on the mortgage loan but we wanted to keep the house and we try to get a loan modification, after almost 3 years we were declined for the loan mod. we never made a payment after the BK discharged and now we just received a NOTICE OF DEFAULT and the bank changed their COURTESY monhtly statement to REGULAR statement,I called the Bank and I was told that because they were granted relief from the automatic stay 3 years ago now I OWE them 600K I told them they can only do a FORECLOSURE on the property and that I have no personal obligation to repay this debt due to the Chap. 7 discharge and they told me NO ,that I better talked to a atty.
answers: Agree with other counsel. Check your credit report too, make sure the loans are being reported correctly as being discharged in bankrutpcy. My knee jerk reaction to a representative telling me this over the phone would have been to laugh out loud. If you can prove that they are attempting to personally collect from you on discharged debt, you can reopen BK case and motion court to sanction creditor for contempt of discharge order. I'd start with a polite letter reminding them that the debt was discharged in your case (attach copy of discharge order). I can't think of anything that would make you liable for this debt other than adversary action in your bankruptcy case claiming fraud, reaffirmation of the loan during the pendency of your case, or post petition refinancing, loan modification application is not refinancing.

I have worked for banks and there are a lot of stupid people that work in the collection department of the bank that know absolutely nothing about bankruptcy law.

Stop wasting your time talking to the collection department and if you want or need to talk to someone at the bank about your liability, talk to the bankruptcy department or the bank legal department.

Should the bank attempt to do anything other than foreclose, see your bankruptcy attorney right away because you will be able to make some money from the bank for violating the bankruptcy discharge order.

Hope this perspective helps!

In general, I agree that you don't owe any money for a discharged debt. There would have to be some sort of interesting legal arrangement to create liability which I doubt took place in your case.

You should be find.

If you want to get this figured out, just record a call or two and bring a discharge violation for the threatened collection actions.

Nothing like a Motion for Contempt to get things in order.

good luck.

",I called the Bank and I was told that because they were granted relief from the automatic stay 3 years ago now I OWE them 600K I told them they can only do a FORECLOSURE on the property "

They are ridiculous if they told you this. Relief from the stay doesn't change anything about the fact that you have likely discharged your mortgage note. You have ZERO personal obligation to pay the note. If you want to keep the house, of course that's different, because the lien remains. But if you walk away, they can't come after you personally at all.
